content: The Act titled "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the recall of retired judges for further service on the Court in accordance with specific requirements. Retired judges must provide written notice of their availability and willingness to be recalled, which is irrevocable. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the recall of retired judges for further service on the Court. Retired judges must provide written notice of their availability, which is irrevocable. The chief judge may recall a recall-eligible retired judge for a period not exceeding 90 days based on the needs of the Court. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the recall of retired judges for up to 90 days based on the Court's needs. If a recall-eligible retired judge declines to serve when recalled, they may be removed from the recall-eligible status. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the recall of retired judges for up to 90 days based on the Court's needs. If a recall-eligible retired judge is unable to perform further service or becomes permanently disabled, they shall be removed from the recall-eligible status. A recalled retired judge may exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. The pay for a recalled retired judge varies based on their retirement status. The pay for a recall-eligible retired judge who retired under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5 is specified in subsection (c) of section 7296. During recall status, the judge will be paid at the rate of pay for active service, minus their annuity under chapter 83 or 84. A recalled judge retired under chapter 83 or 84 is considered a reemployed annuitant under that chapter, with the right to serve in accordance with title 5 provisions. A retired judge under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5 can serve as a reemployed annuitant with pay specified in section 7296. They will be paid at the active service rate minus their annuity, and have the right to serve in accordance with title 5 provisions. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating an individual's service. Fractional parts of a year less than 183 days are disregarded, while 183 days or more are credited as a full year. Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to adjust the retired pay of judges based on their recall status or notice of availability for service in a recalled status. The retired pay of judges is adjusted based on their recall status or notice of availability for service in a recalled status. For judges who did not provide notice of availability, their retired pay is based on the rate at the time of retirement. For recall-eligible judges removed from recall status, their retired pay is based on the pay at the time of removal. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired pay only apply in certain cases. The retired pay of judges is adjusted based on their recall status or notice of availability for service in a recalled status. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired pay only apply in certain cases, such as when the retired pay of a retired chief judge exceeds the annual rate of pay for the chief judge of the court. The retired pay of judges is adjusted based on their recall status or notice of availability for service in a recalled status. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired pay only apply in certain cases to prevent retired pay from exceeding the annual rate of pay for judges of the court. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired pay only apply in certain cases to prevent retired pay from exceeding the annual rate of pay for judges of the court. Additionally, if a regular or reserve member of a uniformed service receiving retired or retainer pay becomes a judge of the court, the retired or retainer pay shall not be paid during the judge's regular active service on the court, but will be resumed or commenced without reduction upon retirement as a judge. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON ACTIVITIES OF RETIRED JUDGES. A new section is added to Chapter 72 of title 38, United States Code, stating that if a retired judge of the Court represents a client in making a claim related to veterans' benefits against the United States, they will forfeit their retired pay for a period of one year. SEC. 7. EARLY RETIREMENT AUTHORITY FOR CURRENT JUDGES TO PROVIDE STAGGERED TERMS. Retirement Authorized for eligible judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims with specific criteria including years of service and age requirements. If multiple judges are eligible, the one with the greatest seniority will retire. If multiple eligible judges provide notice to retire in a specific year, the judge with the most seniority at the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can retire. Judges must give written notice to the President and chief judge by April 1 of the retirement year. In accordance with retirement provisions, eligible judges must provide written notice of retirement by April 1 of the year, with exceptions for 1999 retirements. The retirement date shall be specified and irrevocable, with retirement occurring not earlier than 90 days after notice is provided. A judge retiring under this section must give notice by April 1, with exceptions for 1999 retirements. The retirement date must be specified and is irrevocable, occurring not earlier than 90 days after notice. The retired judge is considered under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code, and the rate of retired pay is determined by a specific formula. Adjustments in retired pay for judges available for recall are subject to specific provisions of title 38, United States Code. An adjustment in annuities under civil service retirement laws applies to retired pay for recall-eligible judges, including those removed from recall status due to disability. The formula for determining retired pay includes a fraction where the numerator is the sum of years of service and age of the judge, and the denominator is 80. The duty of the actuary in determining the present value of payments from the retirement fund for recall-eligible retired judges is clarified in an amendment to section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code.
